data.title: The 46 Most Anticipated Albums of Summer 2023
data.meta_description: New releases to look forward to in the coming months, from King Krule, PJ Harvey, Noname, Foo Fighters, Taylor Swift, and more
data.text:
As festival season approaches, the flies of summer are abuzz with anticipation. While headline pop records dominated last yearâ€™s release cycle, 2023 is set to be a marquee year for a broad spectrum of rock. Foo Fighters and Queens of the Stone Age are back, and there are much-anticipated returns from PJ Harvey, Best Coastâ€™s Bethany Cosentino, King Krule, and even a new album from Radioheâ€” well, not exactly, but Jonny Greenwoodâ€™s collaborative record with Dudu Tassa promises much, as does a new LP from club maestro Clark, executive produced by one Thom Yorke. Killer Mike, Noname, Julie Byrne, and Jenny Lewis are also back after long breaks, and you can never rule out the arrival of that endlessly speculated-upon Rihanna album. Hereâ€™s a rundown of all that and more that weâ€™re looking forward to this summer.

12 Rods: If We Stayed Alive

July 7

During the COVID-19 lockdown, 12 Rods frontman Ryan Olcott found some of the bandâ€™s previously recorded demos and decided to finish them. That has developed into If We Stayed Alive, the Minneapolis bandâ€™s first album since Lost Time came out 21 years ago. â€œThese are songs that I forgot about,â€ Olcott said frankly. â€“Alphonse Pierre

All products featured on Pitchfork are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.

Albert Hammond Jr: Melodies on Hiatus

June 23

Strokes guitarist Albert Hammond Jr. announced his latest album, Melodies on Hiatus, in April. So far, Hammond has shared the first nine songs of the LP, including collaborations with Washington, D.C., rapper GoldLink, Arctic Monkeysâ€™ Matt Helders, and guitarist Steve Stevens. Hammond created the album long-distance with songwriter Simon Wilcox, who wrote the lyrics. â€œI think this is the best collection of music that I have made,â€ Hammond said of the 19-track LP in a statement. â€œI wasnâ€™t trying to make a double album; I wanted to make a deconstruction of a band.â€ â€“Eric Torres

Amaarae: Fountain Baby

June 9

Amaarae, the Ghanaian American pop star, will follow up her 2020 debut, The Angel You Donâ€™t Know, with Fountain Baby in June. Sheâ€™s already shared the slow-burning lead single â€œReckless & Sweet,â€ which promises to continue her spiky, experimental fusion of Afrobeats, hip-hop, and R&B. â€œComing back after so long, I had a lot of time to think and reflect on what I wanted my message to be,â€ Amaarae said in a statement, â€œLast time it was about confidence, this time itâ€™s about love and faith.â€ â€“Eric Torres

Arlo Parks: My Soft Machine

May 26

British singer-songwriter Arlo Parks is back with her second album, My Soft Machine. Itâ€™s the follow-up to 2021 Mercury Prize winner Collapsed in Sunbeams, which also earned Parks a Grammy nomination for Best Alternative Music Album (not to mention Best New Artist). Itâ€™s a record that includes a new collaboration with Phoebe Bridgers titled â€œPegasus.â€ â€“Evan Minsker

Bethany Cosentino: Natural Disaster

July 28

Itâ€™s been almost 15 years since Bethany Cosentino and Bobb Bruno formed the indie-rock duo Best Coast, and, now, Cosentino is stepping out on her own. The guitarist, songwriter, and vocalist announced the news with her new track â€œItâ€™s Fine,â€ the lead single from her solo debut, Natural Disaster. Cosentino also revealed that Best Coast would go on indefinite hiatus. â€œI have heavily identified as â€˜Bethany from Best Coastâ€™ for over a decade, and being anyone other than that has felt challenging for me,â€ Cosentino said. â€œI decided to push myself through the discomfort and go explore being â€¦ just Bethany Cosentino. This record is a product of that experience.â€ The 12-song Natural Disaster was produced by Butch Walker. â€“Madison Bloom

Bonny Doon: Let There Be Music

June 16

Detroit alt-country band Bonny Doon released their last album, Longwave, in 2018. Since then, the group performed as Waxahatcheeâ€™s backing band on 2020â€™s Saint Cloud, and Bonny Doon are now set to return with Let There Be Music, their first album since signing to Anti-. The new record also features Waxahatcheeâ€™s Katie Crutchfield, and includes the singles â€œLet There Be Music,â€ â€œSan Francisco,â€ â€œCrooked Creek,â€ and â€œNaturally.â€ â€œI moved to the Bay Area in 2018 and for the first time in a while, we had one foot somewhere other than Detroit,â€ the bandâ€™s singer and guitarist, Bobby Colombo, said in a statement. â€œWe spent a lot of time on the West Coast, which found its way into the writing, and also provided some distance to reflect more deeply on our hometown.â€ â€“Eric Torres

Brigid Mae Power: Dream From the Deep Well

June 30

A year after 2020â€™s Head Above the Water, Irish singer-songwriter Brigid Mae Power released 2021â€™s Burning Your Light EP, a six-song set of covers. She makes her album-length return with Dream From the Deep Well, billed as â€œfolk music, but not as we know it.â€ The album features a cover of Tim Buckleyâ€™s â€œI Must Have Been Blindâ€ and an original tribute to a primary school teacher and traditional Irish musician who was killed while jogging. So far, Power has shared videos for the title track and the touring contemplation â€œCounting Down.â€ â€“Marc Hogan

Bully: Lucky for You

June 2

Grunge rock band Bully released their last album, Sugaregg, back in 2020. The group, led by Nashville-based musician Alicia Bognanno, will soon release Lucky for You, an album inspired by Bognannoâ€™s dog Mezzi, who died during a period of transition in Bognannoâ€™s life. Bullyâ€™s fourth album is led by the feedback-loaded single â€œDays Move Slow,â€ and features the previously released â€œLose You,â€ featuring Soccer Mommy. â€“Eric Torres

Chief Keef: Almighty So 2

June 9

Almighty So, released in 2013, is one of the most inventive and essential Chief Keef mixtapes. So, naturally, its sequel, nearly a decade later, comes with major expectations. But since the project was announced in October 2022, it has gone through endless pushbacks and failed promises of â€œcoming soon.â€ Originally it was scheduled for January, then April, and now, maybe, this summer. Who knows if it will ever actually see the light of day? There are a couple singles rumored to be on Almighty So 2, like â€œRacks Stuffed Inna Couchâ€ and â€œTony Montana Flow,â€ which is decent proof that the project actually exists. â€“Alphonse Pierre

Christine and the Queens: ParanoÃ¯a, Angels, True Love

June 9

Christine and the Queens wrote his new album, ParanoÃ¯a, Angels, True Love, as the â€œsecond part of an operatic gestureâ€ that also encompassed last yearâ€™s Redcar les adorables Ã©toiles (prologue). Both albums were inspired by Angels in America, Tony Kushnerâ€™s award-winning play chronicling relationships ravaged by the AIDS crisis in 1980s New York. â€œRedcar felt colorful and absurd,â€ Christin and the Queens said in press materials. â€œParanoÃ¯a, Angels, True Love is a key toward heart-opening transformation, a prayer towards the selfâ€”the one that breathes through all the loves it is made of.â€ â€“Madison Bloom

Clark: Sus Dog

May 26

Whatâ€™s Sus Dog? Why, itâ€™s the latest album from British electronic music mainstay Clark. For the first time, Clark is singing on one of his records. The album features several contributions from executive producer Thom Yorke. â€œThe first thing he sent me was him singing about being stuck between two floors and I was already sold,â€ Yorke said in a statement. â€œTo me the way he approached it all wasnâ€™t the usual singer songwriter guff thank god; it mirrored the way he approached all his composition and recording, but this time it had a human face. His face.â€ Sus Dog includes the lead single â€œTown Crank.â€ â€“Evan Minsker

The Clientele: I Am Not There Anymore

July 28

After going on an indefinite hiatus, the Clientele resurfaced in 2017 for their first album in seven years, Music for the Age of Miracles. Fast forward another six years, and the UK indie-rock trio is back with a double album, I Am Not There Anymore. This time, singer and guitarist Alasdair MacLean has said, the Clientele branched out into post-bop jazz, contemporary classical, and electronic music. MacLean, bassist James Hornsey, and drummer Mark Keen don knightsâ€™ armor in the video for the albumâ€™s first single, â€œBlue Over Blue,â€ which billows out with horns, strings, and samples. â€“Marc Hogan

Dave Matthews Band: Walk Around the Moon

May 19

This year, Dave Matthews Band return for a massive tour here on planet Earth behind their new album, Walk Around the Moon. Itâ€™s an album with lofty song titles like â€œBreak Free,â€ â€œMonsters,â€ â€œThe Ocean and the Butterfly,â€ â€œThe Only Thing,â€ and â€œAll You Wanted Was Tomorrow.â€ If all you want is tomorrow, so youâ€™re one day closer to hearing this whole album, hereâ€™s some good newsâ€”lead single â€œMadmanâ€™s Eyesâ€ is out now. â€“Evan Minsker

Dudu Tassa / Jonny Greenwood: Jarak Qaribak

June 9

Radioheadâ€™s Jonny Greenwood and Israeli musician Dudu Tassa are teaming up for Jarak Qaribak, a collaborative LP whose title translates to â€œYour Neighbor Is Your Friend.â€ Greenwood, who previously collaborated with Israeli singer and composer Shye Ben Tzur on 2015â€™s Junun, has described the process of creating the new album as similar in scope. â€œYou have all these scales which donâ€™t conform to western major/minor scales,â€ he explained in a statement. â€œItâ€™s very hard to impose a chord sequence on these melodies. It usually makes them collapse. Itâ€™s like reducing the resolution on a colour photo until itâ€™s just squares.â€ So far, the duo has shared lead singles â€œAshufak Shayâ€ and â€œYa Mughir al-Ghazalaâ€ ahead of the release. â€“Eric Torres

Feeble Little Horse: Girl With Fish

June 9

Make it past the prickly layer of scuzzy noise-rock in Feeble Little Horseâ€™s music and youâ€™re rewarded with a mellow dose of alt-pop sweetness courtesy of Lydia Slocumâ€™s vocals. The Pittsburgh quartet broke onto the scene in 2021 with its debut album, Hayday, and signed to Saddle Creek shortly afterward. On their upcoming sophomore LP, Girl With Fish, Feeble Little Horse further strengthen their take on noise pop. Get a taste for it with lead single â€œTin Manâ€ ahead of the albumâ€™s release on June 9. Plus, read Pitchforkâ€™s new Rising feature â€œMeet Feeble Little Horse, the Young Noise-Pop Band Repping Pittsburgh DIY.â€ â€“Nina Corcoran

Foo Fighters: But Here We Are

June 2

It was a heartbreaking year for Foo Fighters. Following the death of their beloved drummer Taylor Hawkins, the band made a new album called But Here We Are thatâ€™s coming this summer. Produced with their frequent collaborator Greg Kurstin, its album announcement referred to the work as a â€œbrutally honest and emotionally raw response to everything Foo Fighters endured over the last year.â€ It was announced with the new single â€œRescued.â€ â€“Evan Minsker

Hayden Pedigo: The Happiest Times I Ever Ignored

June 30

The Happiest Times I Ever Ignored is the latest record from Texas guitarist Hayden Pedigo, who last issued a set of acoustic compositions with 2021â€™s Letting Go. Pedigoâ€™s playing style is light, warm, and open, drawing inspiration from a wide variety of fingerpickers and other eccentrics without succumbing to imitation. Occasionally anointed with pedal steel, Pedigoâ€™s songs unwind with pensive ease, maintaining a loose air of mystique. Theyâ€™re effective one by one as five-minute escapes or in an album-length oasis, inviting contemplation and compassion. Pedigo announced The Happiest Times I Ever Ignored with the track â€œElsewhereâ€ in April. â€“Allison Hussey

Home Is Where: The Whaler

June 16

After rolling out one of the best rock albums of 2021 with their debut full-length, I Became Birds, Home Is Where are back with another dose of heart-on-sleeve emo meets Elephant 6 indie rock. The Palm Coast, Florida, band is calling The Whaler, its sophomore effort, a concept album â€œabout getting used to things getting worse.â€ Although it was spurred by a nervous breakdown and the spiraling thoughts that culminated in its wake, The Whaler has moments of blissful harmonica, cyclical tape loops, and tender sentiments buried beneath lyrics of dystopian defeat. â€“Nina Corcoran

Janelle MonÃ¡e: The Age of Pleasure

June 9

Since releasing her third LP, Dirty Computer, in 2018, the alien superstar Janelle MonÃ¡e has spent more of her time branching out into short fiction and screen acting, publishing The Memory Librarian in 2022 and picking up roles in a Knives Out sequel and a Josephine Baker biography series. Now, sheâ€™s back with The Age of Pleasure. After sharing the new single â€œFloatâ€ with Seun Kuti and Egypt 80 in February, MonÃ¡e followed it with â€œLipstick Loverâ€ and the full album announcement in May. â€œI definitely have had an opportunity to evolve and grow and to tap into the things that bring me pleasure, the things that perhaps I should rethink and rework,â€ she told Apple Musicâ€™s Zane Lowe about developing the project. â€“Allison Hussey

Jay Worthy / Roc Marciano: Nothing Bigger Than the Program

May 26

Vancouver-raised, Compton-molded rapper Jay Worthy has been a steady hand in hip-hop for a while now. On Nothing Bigger Than the Program he teams up with another Mr. Reliable in Roc Marciano, who produced the entire album. This wonâ€™t be the first time Marciano has given out the full-project production sauce, most recently he was behind the boards on Stove God Cooksâ€™ Reasonable Drought and Flee Lordâ€™s Delgado. As for Jay Worthy and Marciano, they have collaborated before on Worthy and Larry Juneâ€™s joint album, 2 Pâ€™z in a Pod, and lately have been on tour together. â€“Alphonse Pierre

Jenny Lewis: Joyâ€™all

June 9

Jenny Lewis penned some of the songs on her new solo album, Joyâ€™all, during a pre-pandemic tour. The rest emerged from a week-long virtual songwriting workshop hosted by Beck in 2021. â€œThe challenge was to write one song every day for seven days, with guidelines from Beck,â€ Lewis wrote in press materials. â€œThe guidelines would be prompts like â€˜write a song with 1-4-5 chord progression,â€™ â€˜write a song with only cliches,â€™ or â€˜write in free form style.â€™ The first song I submitted to the group was â€˜Puppy and a Truck.â€™â€ Joyâ€™all was produced by Dave Cobb and engineered and mixed by Greg Koller; it also features contributions from Jon Brion. â€“Madison Bloom

Jess Williamson: Time Ainâ€™t Accidental

June 9

After collaborating with Waxahatcheeâ€™s Katie Crutchfield for last yearâ€™s I Walked with You A Ways, Texas-reared singer-songwriter Jess Williamson returns with another solo LP. Time Ainâ€™t Accidental arrives three years after her last album, 2020â€™s Sorceress. Williamson draws up vivid, sensual imagery, painting with twangy tones and synthy beats. The recordâ€™s title track is an ode to the long, winding paths toward falling in love, and she contemplates the heartache of chasing after free spirits on the albumâ€™s first single, â€œHunter.â€ Williamson also shared â€œChasing Spiritsâ€ as a preview of Time Ainâ€™t Accidental. â€“Allison Hussey

Jessy Lanza: Love Hallucination

July 28

Love Hallucination is a collection of songs that Jessy Lanza first wrote for other artists; yet, after pushing her own limits, these experiments in style proved enticing enough to lead her to rewrite and record them herself. Building on her 2021 DJ-Kicks release, Lanza weaves propulsive dancefloor bangers with sultry downtempo jams. â€œIâ€™ve never written explicitly about orgasms or played saxophone on one of my records before,â€ Lanza said. â€œBut these choices made sense on Love Hallucination.â€ A trust fall in album form, Love Hallucination promises to show what happens when an artist finds faith in her own deconstruction. â€“Matthew Ismael Ruiz

Joanna Sternberg: Iâ€™ve Got Me

June 30

Thereâ€™s something inherently pure about Joanna Sternbergâ€™s music thatâ€™s reminiscent of the first time you heard a classic folk record. Their guitar chords are evocative yet simple, their words truthful and eager. On Iâ€™ve Got Me, Sternberg sophomore album and the follow-up to 2019â€™s Then I Try Some More, Sternberg sits upright, takes a deep breath, and lets it all spill out: the tiny thrill of making a friend laugh, the specific exhaustion of hustling in New York, the thoughts that consume your mind before they help you make sense of it all. Iâ€™ve Got Me is a dare not to fall in love with all the traits that make Sternberg a captivating singer-songwriter. â€“Nina Corcoran

Julie Byrne: The Greater Wings

July 7

Six years ago, Julie Byrne unleashed the gentle-sounding Not Even Happiness, the album she worked on with collaborator Eric Littman. They began to work on her follow-up, The Greater Wings, until Littmanâ€™s death in June 2021. Byrne then went to the Catskills and finished the album with producer Alex Somers. The lead single of her upcoming 10-track album is called â€œSummer Glass.â€ â€“Alphonse Pierre

Kari Faux: Real B*tches Donâ€™t Die!

May 26

The South will be the source of inspiration on Kari Fauxâ€™s upcoming album, Real B*tches Donâ€™t Die!, an homage to her roots. Hailing from Little Rock, Arkansas, hip-hop, R&B, and gospel will co-exist on the project, which will be her first since 2021â€™s Lowkey Superstar (Deluxe). Multiple singles have already been released, including â€œMake a Wish,â€ â€œMe First,â€ and â€œTurninâ€™ Heads.â€ To hammer home the theme, Southern legends Big K.R.I.T., Devin the Dude, and the late Gangsta Boo feature on the new album. â€“Alphonse Pierre

Killer Mike: Michael

June 16

Itâ€™s been more than a decade since Killer Mikeâ€™s last solo album, R.A.P. Music. In that time heâ€™s been anything but quiet: Releasing four albums with El-P as Run the Jewels, breaking out into television, and becoming one of the loudest political voices in all of hip-hop. His upcoming album, Michael, which will be his official return to solo material, is a self-described â€œorigin story.â€ The recent single â€œDonâ€™t Let the Devilâ€ is a soulful joint with El-P and Thankugoodsir; he wrote a note about the song on Instagram: â€œI want to time travel and tell 12-year-old #MICHAEL that he dropped a ğŸ”¥ song with his rap potna El-Pâ€¦Life is great kid.â€ â€“Alphonse Pierre

King Krule: Space Heavy

June 9

Space Heavy is Archy Marshallâ€™s first King Krule LP in three years, following 2020â€™s Man Alive! Marshall was inspired by the concept of â€œthe space betweenâ€ as he was writing the new album in London and Liverpool between 2020 and 2022. He recorded Space Heavy with producer Dilip Harris, guitarist Jack Towell, bassist James Wilson, saxophonist Ignacio Salvadores, and drummer George Bass. Upon announcing the new record, Marshall shared lead single â€œSeaforthâ€ along with a music video directed by Jocelyn Anquetil. The clip stars Marshall, his band, and two happy dogs. â€“Madison Bloom

Lucinda Williams: Stories From a Rock n Roll Heart

June 30

Americana icon Lucinda Williams will return this June with Stories From a Rock n Roll Heartâ€”her first album since recovering from a stroke in 2020. The new record features guest spots from Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Bandâ€™s Patti Scialfa, who joined Williams on the lead single, â€œNew York Comeback.â€ The married couple also appears on the as-yet-unreleased song â€œRock n Roll Heart.â€ Williams enlisted the likes of Angel Olsen, Margo Price, and the Replacementsâ€™ Tommy Stinson as backup singers on select tracks of the album, too. Stories From a Rock n Roll Heart follows Williamsâ€™ 2020 LP, Good Souls Better Angels. The singer-songwriter recently published her memoir, Donâ€™t Tell Anybody The Secrets I Told You. â€“Madison Bloom

Mandy, Indiana: Iâ€™ve Seen a Way

May 19

Mandy, Indiana catherine-wheeled out of Manchester in 2021 with a darkly alluring EP titled with only an ellipsis. On May 19, a new sentence begins: The British bandâ€™s debut album promises a battery of industrial noise, warehouse-ready rave beats, and antic Franglais vocals from mantra-incanting singer Valentine Caulfield. Lead single â€œInjury Detail,â€ produced by techno pugilists Giant Swan, set the tone with an incendiary display of simmering synths, menacing mantras, pounding drums, and guitars hammered horribly out of shapeâ€”a banger, in every sense. â€“Jazz Monroe

Mega Bog: End of Everything

May 19

End of Everything is the Mexican Summer debut of Erin Elizabeth Birgyâ€™s Mega Bog. After breaking out with a series of idiosyncratic, folky pop records, Birgy modulates her sage observations to a synthpop frequency on the new LP. Making the album, she got sober, which evinced an impatience for the intellectualized â€œsecret codesâ€ of more austere songwriting. â€œI no longer wanted to hide behind difficult music,â€ she said in press materials. â€œI was curious to give others the same with the music I create; to make music someone could use to explore drama, playfulness, and dancing, to shake the trauma loose.â€ â€“Jazz Monroe

Meshell Ndegeocello: The Omnichord Real Book

June 16

Bassist and vocalist Meshell Ndegeocello calls upon an impressive roster of friends for The Omnichord Real Book, a sweeping and dense work that knits together jazz, soul, funk, rock, hip-hop, gospel, and even bits of childrenâ€™s songs. With Jeff Parker, Brandee Younger, Joan as Police Woman, and others joining her across the LP, Ndegeocello processes pain, doubt, and personal growth. She transforms her struggles into moody, spiritual meditations and passionate bursts of triumph. â€œI really, really, really love my pain so much,â€ Ndegeocello growls on â€œClear Water,â€ with a â€œRrah!â€ to emphasize her point. With a 73-minute runtime, The Omnichord Real Book asks for ample attention, but its rewards are so numerous that every minute is worth the investment. â€“Allison Hussey

Militarie Gun: Life Under the Gun

June 23

Last year, Los Angeles post-hardcore quintet Militarie Gun issued All Roads Lead to the Gun (Deluxe), a record compiling two previous EPs and four new songs. Now, the band is gearing up to drop its debut album, Life Under the Gun. The 12-track LP includes recent single â€œVery High,â€ which was inspired by â€œthe desire to escape the embarrassment of day to day life as much as possible,â€ as lead singer Ian Shelton revealed in a press release. â€“Madison Bloom

Miya Folick: Roach

May 26

After releasing her 2007 EP last year, Los Angeles-based pop artist Miya Folick announced her second LP, Roach, in January. She described it as â€œan album about trying to get to the core of what life really is.â€ Folick released â€œGet Out of My Houseâ€ as the first official single from the album. Roach includes all of the material from 2007 plus a few more new tracks, such as the recent single â€œCockroach.â€ â€“Allison Hussey

Nation of Language: Strange Disciple

September 15

Strange Disciple is the third album from Brooklyn synthpop trio Nation of Language, and first that wasnâ€™t created and released outside of a pandemic lockdown. The title is drawn from the single â€œSole Obsession,â€ and means â€œone who finds themself an adherent to a subject that is probably not worth the devotion,â€ according to a quote from the band. Nation of Language have also shared the single â€œWeak in Your Lightâ€ ahead of the release. â€“Eric Torres

Noname: Sundial

TBA

Over the last few years, Nonameâ€™s focus has been expanding her book club and racial justice outreach. But, in July, sheâ€™s due to follow-up her 2018 album, Room 25, with Sundial, which she announced on Instagram with a message that provided little more information. She hasnâ€™t released much music in the nearly five years between records, but did get into a spat with J. Cole, resulting in one of the most impressive and dismissive diss records in recent memory in â€œSong 33,â€ and she put out the single â€œRainforestâ€ in 2021. Sundial will be a welcomed return for one of hip-hopâ€™s strongest voices. â€“Alphonse Pierre

Peter Gabriel: I/O

TBA

If you looked up into the night sky and gazed upon a full moon this year, its glow has heralded a new song from the great Peter Gabriel. It all appears to be leading up the release of I/O, his long-awaited new album. Thus far heâ€™s shared â€œPanopticom,â€ â€œThe Court,â€ â€œPlaying for Time,â€ â€œI/O,â€ and â€œFour Kinds of Horses.â€ Gabriel has also announced some tour dates behind all this new lunar music. â€“Evan Minsker

PJ Harvey: I Inside the Old Year Dying

July 7

Seven years since The Hope Six Demolition Project, PJ Harvey is set to return with her 10th studio album. Inspired by Harveyâ€™s booklength poem, Orlam, the improvisatory album was made with producers Flood and John Parish, longtime collaborators of hers. In the build-up, she released a video for the new single â€œA Childâ€™s Question, August,â€ and has been reissuing past works like the recent B-Sides, Demos & Rarities. In a press release, Harvey described the new album as â€œa resting space, a solace, a comfort, a balmâ€”which feels timely for the times weâ€™re in.â€ â€“Alphonse Pierre

Queens of the Stone Age: In Times New Romanâ€¦

June 16

With the lead single â€œEmotion Sicknessâ€ from their forthcoming new album, In Times New Romanâ€¦, Queens of the Stone Age showed that theyâ€™re sticking to the aesthetic formula as muscular hard rock guitars underpin Joshua Hommeâ€™s glam-adjacent vocal melodies. Itâ€™s the bandâ€™s first album in six years, and, for Homme, Troy Van Leeuwen, Dean Fertita, Michael Shuman, and Jon Theodoreâ€™s latest full-length for Matador, they recorded at Hommeâ€™s Pink Duck Studios with help from mixer Mark Rankin. Their go-to collaborator Boneface is behind the grim artwork. There is a song called â€œCarnavoyeur.â€ â€“Evan Minsker

Rihanna

TBA

In the days leading up to Rihannaâ€™s Super Bowl stand, fans were abuzz with hopeful speculation that the marquee event would be the launchpad for a new album announcement. Instead, she revealed another major life development: her second pregnancy with A$AP Rocky, following the birth of their first child last May. Since issuing Anti in 2016, Rihanna has said that her next LP will bend toward dancehall, claiming that sheâ€™s worked on more than 500 demos for the project. As of right now, the latest major Rihanna material is â€œLift Me Up,â€ a one-off for the Black Panther: Wakanda Forever soundtrack thatâ€™s picked up a few major award nominations. â€œI want it to be this year,â€ she said of a new record in February. So do we, Rihanna, so do we. â€“Allison Hussey

SnÃµÃµper: Super SnÃµÃµper

July 14

Nashville punk group SnÃµÃµper are gearing up to release their debut album, Super SnÃµÃµper. In the time since their 2020 formation, SnÃµÃµper have garnered attention for their wild live shows and EPs, ultimately getting signed by Third Man. On Super SnÃµÃµper, the band further evolves its sound by throwing everything at the wall over the course of 14 tracks, including the single â€œPod.â€ SnÃµÃµper are at their happiest while sprinting between riled-up punk, garage rock, and new wave, so prepare for your heart rate to spike when tagging along for the ride. â€“Nina Corcoran

Sparks: The Girl Is Crying in Her Latte

May 26

After getting the documentary treatment and penning a star-studded musical, Sparks are returning with a new album, The Girl Is Crying in Her Latte. Brothers Ron and Russell Mael are perhaps the greatest comedy duo to emerge from the new wave scene, and they havenâ€™t lost their bizarro sense of humor in the past five decades. Sparks released the title track from the record along with a music video starring Cate Blanchett dancing wildly in a canary yellow suit. The Girl Is Crying in Her Latte also marks the bandâ€™s first album for Island Records in 47 years, following 1976â€™s Big Beat. â€“Madison Bloom

Squid: O Monolith

June 9

Squid electrified the UK festival circuit with an anthemic, yelpy spin on the acerbic post-punk that has prevailed since Sleaford Mods brought monologuing back into vogue. The bandâ€™s tentacles have since reached further afield, into sonically nuanced (and sometimes proggier) realms. Recent single â€œSwing (In a Dream),â€ from second album, O Monolith, shares airspace with The Bends and â€™90s Modest Mouse: with bigger riffs and deeper grooves, but more fraught and intimate, too. â€“Jazz Monroe

Taylor Swift: Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version)

July 7

Leave it to Taylor Swift to make every album announcement a real surprise. During the first of her multi-night stint in Nashville for the Eras Tour, Swift revealed that Speak Now is the next album to get her re-record treatment. Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version) comes with six previously unreleased tracks and will arrive on July 7. â€œThe songs that came from this time in my life were marked by their brutal honesty, unfiltered diaristic confessions and wild wistfulness,â€ Swift said. â€œI love this album because it tells a tale of growing up, flailing, flying and crashingâ€¦ and living to speak about it.â€ Swift was much younger when she wrote the crux of the original album, which means this new version may carry some of the wisdom that comes with being a 33-year-old. â€“Nina Corcoran

Water From Your Eyes: Everyoneâ€™s Crushed
